title: Stay With Me
composer: Sam Smith, James Napier & William Phillips

musicalLanguage.description: A gospel-tinged pop song built on just three chords: Am, F, and C. The simplicity is its power — the emotional weight comes from the vocal melody and the gospel-soul harmonic flavor. This beginner arrangement uses block chords in the left hand with a straightforward vocal melody in the right.
musicalLanguage.structure: Verse-Chorus feel (8 bars) — Am-F-C repeated with subtle melodic variation
keyMoments: Bars 1-2: Am to F — the minor-to-major shift gives the gospel flavor
Bars 3-4: C major — the resolution that the ear craves
Bars 5-8: The same progression with the melody reaching higher — building to an emotional peak
teachingGoals: Three-chord song — Am, F, C in root position
Playing with a soulful, slightly behind-the-beat feel
Connecting simple chords to create emotional impact
styleTips: Play with a relaxed, soulful feel — slightly behind the beat, never ahead
The left hand chords should have a soft, warm attack
Think gospel choir — there is weight and warmth in every chord change

measures.teachingNote: A minor — the melody repeats E before stepping down. Soulful and direct.
F major — the melody relaxes to C. Feel the gospel warmth in the F chord.
C major — the melody descends E-D-C. The resolution feels like a deep breath.
Hold and rest — give the phrase space to breathe. Silence is part of the music.
A minor — the melody reaches higher this time, up to A4. Building intensity.
F major — melody peaks and settles. The gospel feel intensifies.
C major — the melody winds down with a gentle ornamental turn.
Landing on C over Am — a bittersweet ending. The minor chord under a major melody note.
